intro: Synadenium piscatorium, commonly known as the fish poison plant, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae, which includes many plants with toxic properties. The plant is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in summer. It produces a milky sap that contains toxic alkaloids, which can be used as a fish poison. Due to its toxic nature, it is often avoided in agricultural settings and requires careful handling.
